edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:53): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, is it easy to modify your survey tool to check how often the adoption agency algorithm is triggered? Especially the clone node operation in it...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:59): If there's somewhere in the html5lib code where it could poke some value that I could read out again after parsing, then I guess that'd be easy enough

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:02): (But "survey tool" makes it sound more impressive and useful than just being the non-representative collection of a couple of thousand pages with a parser being called on them in a loop which is all it really is :-) )
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:08): hehe
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:08): I think you'd have to make such a value yourself
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:14): 6. Let a bookmark note the position of the formatting element in the list of active formatting elements...
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:14): hmm, I guess that line should be rephrased a little
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:14): (step 6 of the adoption agency)
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:16): oh nvm, i understand it now, note is used as a verb here
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I ought to have time this afternoon to try looking at that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:29): cool
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:29): 425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72, btw, I'd aim for making a full parser at first and create filtering tools for it later
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:30): 425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72, that makes it more usable for other people who want to use it where support for <blah> and <link> is important
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:30): yeah, that's sort of what i'm doing now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:30): cool :)
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:30): but first i need the adoption agency working properly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:33): It seems worrying that the adoption agency sometimes cuts its children into multiple pieces
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:34): it clones them
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:34): and distributes them among parents afterwards
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:35): But the content of the original tags gets split apart and spread between all the clones
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:36): I'm sure that kind of thing can't be legal
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:45): I need to do something about the tree construction‚Ä¶ but probably better to get the other stuff working fix :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:45): *first
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:49): where in the algorithm do P elements close elements such as A and B?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:49): why would <p> close them?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:50): <a><p>test</p></a> is legal
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:50): or really, sweet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:50): well, "legal"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:50): <b><p>test</p></b> should work too
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:50): yeah, i know what you mean :p
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:51): <b><p>test</b></p> makes things interesting...

425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:53): hmm, but when I look at the testcase with the code "<a><p>X<a>Y</a>Z</p></a>" in http://html5lib.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/tests/tree-construction/tests1.dat , the parser closes the first A element when it sees the P element
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): you make incorrect assumptions
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): the magic happens the moment you hit the second <a>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): not when you hit <p>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:16): curses the internal subset
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:23): FWIW: We won't drop support for UTF-32
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:27): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: why not?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:27): There's no good reason not to support it
